column4: so basically I wanted to know how I can either restore the config files or find out what failsafe mode does differently
hey icky, welcome to my nightmare
my gnome works PERFECT in failsafe mode, all my customizations, programs I set to run at startup, etc
heres the thing, I created a new user, test, and test has the same exact problem
so no one can think of anything that failsafe mode does differently from normal startup that wouldn't be specific to my home directory?
it has been there for a 100 years, will be there for a 100 more, and it's on any unix I can imagine running
vi, vim same thing really, if you can manage your way around one you can manage your way around the other

so anyways, I am considering doing a `apt-get -y remove gnome && apt-get -y install gnome`, anyone wanna tell me why this is probably a really stupid idea (or not) I have only been using a debian based distro for about a week now
mainly because gnome is a meta-package, and not the right meta-package for ubuntu
the gnome package you see is a holdover from debian; ubuntu uses ubuntu-desktop to install the equivalent system

if you do do apt-cache depends gnome (list what packages are installed by the gnome meta-package) and compare that to apt-cache depends ubuntu-desktop, you'll see two ways of using debian package management
depends on what you're trying to fix, and I couldn't look up that far
so what your saying is i could use apt get to remove and re-install either gnome or ubuntu-desktop, which are both going to affect different config files and binaries ? I think>
no. The only way I know of to completely remove gnome (and then reinstall it) is to use debfoster.
but personally I'd reinstall rather than use debfoster
